document.text: Unusually Large A ttendanceInter esting M urder Trial. There was au unusually large at tendance of the sovereigns from every part of the county on last Thursday, the regular term of the County Court. Mauy of them were doubtless attracted by the wide spread interest in the trial of the negroes George Flowers aud Charles Robertson who had been indicted aud imprisoned for the murder of Bob Boler near Spout Spring, on the uight of the 4th of January last. The parties indicted and the import ant witnesses had all made fiatly contradictory statements and an im penetrable mystery seemed to overhang the tragedy. There bad been a negro frolic and dance, the parliciputs, male and female,- be coming uproarious from whiskey. On the way home Bob Boler, Letitia Carson, George Flowers aud Charles Robertson were walking together apart from the othei s. A scuffle en sued between George Flowers and Bob Boler they were separated aud the puny walked on a few paces when pistol shots were heard and Bob Boler fell to the ground mort ally wounded, ana his dead body was left in the middle of the road. These were all of the facts about which there was direct, uncontra- dicted testimony. A jury was empannelled in the case of George Flowers, without de lay or difficulty,consisting of the fol io wiug persons F. G. Thorpe, C. M. Diiukard, Seaborn Gilbert, Fielding Rogers, Ro. W. Morris, Jas. W. Paris, Samuel J. Lee, Samuel Rauson, P. H. Wooldridge, T. L. Cralie, W. T. Marshall, and Alouzu Hamilton. Mr. S. L. Ferguson, the uewly appointed Commonwealths Attorney, assisted by Hon. H. D. Flood, prosecuted the case and Col. R. B. Poore defended the accused. Mr. Fergusou managed the case with ability and gave abundant evi dence that he will make an efficient States Attorney. Col. Poore and Mr. Flood threw their utmost ener gies iuto the case, aud it is unneces sary to add that their efforts were vigorous and brilliant. The case occupied two days, and on Friday alternoou the jury brought in a ver dict of guilty and awarded the ac cused tea years in the peuitentiary. The counsel for the Commonwealth demanded only a verdict for murder iu the second decree, for which the punishment is confinement in the penitentiary admitting to the jury that they were unable to establish the ingredient of premeditation necessary - to elevate the homicide to murder iu the first degree. Col. Poore moved the Court to set aside the verdict and award the prisoner a new trial, upon the following grounds First That the verdict was con trary to the law and the evidence. document.text: There is to be no November term of circuit court here this time. Judge Hundley wrote to Clerk Hubbard about the .mat ter and Mr. Hubbard conferred with the members of County Board of Health and with other prominent ciiizns here, and wrote the Judge that it was the concensus of opnioa here that it would be unwise for the peo pie to oome together in public gathering at this time. Dr. Morriss, one of the mem bers of the Health Board, has been ill of influenza for the past week. But Drs. Randolph and Mitchell, the other mem bers of the Board, met here and discussed the question of the public schools being reopened. Lhe Board deoided that schools could reopeh last Monday, bui that district seno-ri boards would have the right to orde any schools hot to open, wher- there is still danger of th spread of the prevailing die -tase. . A great number of farmers have raised sorghum and they have been making the m las- ses the past week. I sold 25 barrels of corn on Saturday at 8 a barrel, and some changed hands at 9. Strange t say, corn is not wtll cured, notwithstanding the lovely weather we have had. I have a new Westenholm pocket knife I prize very high y, and I lost it. Tben T pray ed earnestly that 1 might find it, nd next morning I went a half mile to the place where 1 thought I loit it, and sure enough there it was. Mr. G. W. Newton leaves to day for New York to see his son, Grandison Newton, who has been ill with pneumonia, following influenza. This is Mr. Newtons second trip to Bee his son. Mr. H. Turner has decided not to teach school this year. His mother is old and feeble and needs him with her and besides, be has his crop at home to attend to. It is expected that Misses Bessie Patteson and Appling Moss will teach 8t. Andrews sohool. Mr. G. I. Taylor, who moved to Richmond with his family, is not pleased with the Capital city and contemplates moving back to his old home in the near future. Veal calves shipped to Rich mond have been bringing 18c a pound, Dressed fowls have been sell ing at prices to almost cause the ladies to sell their reserve stock. There will be no educational conference in Richmond this year, as the pupils and teach ers have lost so much time al ready. The School Fair and Agricul tural Fair, as stated before, are to be held at on and the same time at this place, on the 28th and 29th November Letters from the soldier boys in Fiance have come in to their people freely of late. Two let ters from D W. Patteson reach ed his home people last week Mr James Young and his wife have decided to move to Louisa county, where Mr. Y hss purchased a farm. We county people regret to give up such neighbors as these. Mr. John Poore has purchas ed a farm and will move down near the Cumberland line. Mr. Poore is a practical farmer,who makes farming pay.

document.text: The riasons Banquet. Friday night Monroe Lodge of Masons entertained the village at a banquet given at Hotel Atwood. Notwithstanding the dowupour of lain the invited guests began to come iu at the appointed hour and 125 seats were occupied at the ta ble. The tables aud dining room were beautifully decorated and it seemed as if the host and hostess of this popular hostelry knew just what they were about After supper Worshipful Master W. J. Trent, who acted as toast master for the occasion, announced that Dr. G. B Taylor would respoud to the toast of Our GuestsRight welcome lo our banquet all The Doctor responded in his usual fine style and quite sustained his reputation asau after dinnerspeaker. Hoii. H. D. Flood then responded to the toast, Masonry Founded 4000 years before the birth of Christ coeval with the organization of soci ety, and next to the Christian re ligion, the most potent agency for good. .Mr. Flood spoke for about twenty minutes and made the speech of the evening. He showed his bearers that he was a very bright Mason. Col. Poore followed Mr. Flood in responding to the toast, The Ladies.  W. .man, blest partner o f joys and woes. Even in the darkest hour of earthly ill, Untarnished yet thy fond affeetion glows, Throbs with each pulse aud beats with every thrill. Col. Poore demonstrated the fact that hs was a student of ancient history and a close observer of thrilling events during the mem orable campaigns of 61-65. The evening was highly enjoyed hy all whose good fortune it was to he present, and all wished the Masoi.s a new lease on life.

document.text: The interment of Mr. Joel F. Taylor took place this morning at the burial ground of the Flood fam ily, six miles from West Appomat tox. He was the son of the late Maj. Thomas P. Taylor. His moth er is the sister of Capt. R. B. Poore, and first cousin of Maj. Joel W. Flood. The caBe is a particularly sad one. Deceased was an intelligent, inter esting, and universally popular young mau of about 22 years of age. He had been under treatment for several months at the Johns Hop kins Hospital, Baltimore, b u t. medi cal skill was unavailing to arrest the malady that had laid its remorseless hand upon his youthful frame. His bereaved mother has the deepest sympathy of a wide circle of friends. The remains were brought from Baltimore yesterday. Many friends from a distance came to mingle their grief aud sympathy with those of the immediate family con nection in this vicinity.

document.text: T he D ea th o f M rs. M cK inney. Seldom has a death of a member of our community affected everyone so sadly as that of Mrs. Lelia McKin ney, wife of Mr. Frank W. McKin ney. The announcement of her death and its suddenness sent a shock through the entire community. On Monday last she was taken very ill at about 11 oclock at night, and the conditions being very alarming,riders were sent out in all directions for physicians. Drs. W. H. Abbitt and A. A. Rice were found and promptly responded to the summons. They did all that was possible to alleviate her sufferings and to tide her over the dangerous illness, but when the evening shades of Tuesday began to fall, Mrs McKinney passed away. The hour of her death was 5 oclock Many of her friends were telegraphed for from Lynchburg and Richmond and among those who came by the earliest train were Mr. and Mrs. Wal ter McKinney,Mrs. Poore, of Lynch burg, and Mr. Charles Peers, of Rich mond. The funeral services, which oc curred yesterday at 4 oclock, were conducted by Rev. E. M. Craig, as sisted by Rev. W. S. Royall. The re mains of the deceased were interred in the old family cemetery, just the rear of the house. A very large number of friends and relatives were present to witness the last sad rites. Mrs. McKinney was a native of Appomattox, having passed her life, until a few months ago, at OldAp- pomattox Court-House. She was a daughter of Mr. Geb. Peers, our pre sent county clerk. She was married only last May, and at the time of her death was thirty-three years of age. She was a member of the Presby terian church, and her character as a Christian and as a womanwas sfffih that it would be almost an intrusion to touch upon it. As her pastor, Mr. Craig, said, she never let a day pass without showing by some kindly j act the impress of Christs spirit ppon her.

document.text: sister Southern States, which had already seceded. The call went out for volunteers to defend the firesides of the Old Do minion. Appomattox County responded nobly. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. From 1870 to the present has been a period of rebuilding and achievement. From its creation the County has been served until now by the following Officers CIRCUIT JUDGESJudges G. A. Wingfield, J. D. Hors- rv, Sam Coleman, George J. Hundley, Robt. F. Hutcheson and Joel W. Flood. COUNTY JUDGESLewis Daniel Isbell, Henry T. Par-  rish and David A. Christian. TRIAL JUSTICEST. R. Horseley and L. F. Ferguson. COUNTY CLERKSJohn T. Bocock, Henry F. Bocock, Geo. T. Peers, Geo. W. Abbitt, John Rolfe Horsley and Claude W. Smith. , COMMONWEALTHS ATTORNEYSThos. S. Bocock, L. D. Isbell, Crawford Jones, Edward Woodson, T. J. Thornhill, David A. Christian, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson, Joel W. Flood and W. M. Abbitt. SHERIFFSJoel Watkins, Geo. T. Peers, William Paris, Wilson Hix, W. T. Johnson, Wm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, T. B. Bryant, S. P. Coleman, Frank W. McKinney and H. W. Mc Kinney. COMMISSIONERS OF THE REVENUEThos W. Johns, Isaac Adams, Andrew B. Baker, John W. Gilliam, Geo. W. Ab bitt, Van Gilliam, Wm. Statham, L. E. Smith, H. C. Babcock, E. R. Abbott and J. H. OBrien. COUNTY TREASURERSWm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, S. R. Franklin, D. Mott Robertson, R. F. Burke and R. L. Burke. SUPERINTENDENTS OF SCHOOLSC. H. Chilton, J. B. Bristow, J. K. Hannah, N. R. Featherston and J. A. Burke. STATE SENATORSThe County has furnished the fol lowing State SenatorsCol. Wyatt Elliott, Col. Samuel D. Mc Dearmon, Col. Robt. B. Poore, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson and Chas. T. Moses. HOUSE OF DELEGATESThe following citizens of the county have served in the House of Delegates Col, Samuel D. McDearmon, Zachariah Cheatham, Crawford Jones, R. P. Poore, Joel W. Flood, Thos. S. Bocock, James Watkins, D. Mott Robertson, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, J. W. Harwood, Ster ling C. Stratton, Willis H. Ligon, J. R. Horsley, J. C. Jones, A. B. Thornhill, T. J. Stratton, J. W. Cawthorn and R. L. Burke. The Constitution of 1902, abolished the County Court, the duties of which were transferred to the Circuit Court, the County Clerk and the Board of Supervisors.

document.text: sisted in part of the fair sex. The snccessfnl debaters were Messrs. J. R. Hill, E. W. Taylor, and J, M. Miles. The remainder of the evening was passed in a series of games, both pleasant and profitable. Refresh ments were also served. - Even on Saturday night, the joyous spirit of the . community not being quelled, Hotel Appomattox was for the third time the scene of a gay as semblage, and the welkin was made to ring by the effervescence of delight that babbled from tbe overflowing cup of Xmas. All of this seemed but a prepara tion for the brilliant afgpir of tbe coming week for, many days before, tasteful cards of invitation had been issued by Mr. and Mrs. J. R. Atwood, announcing that on Monday, Jan.. 1st there Would be a reception at their lome, which is known by the pretty name qf Cherwood. Auspicious, was the weather not a clond to mar the aznre pros pect of the heavens, and jnst enough frost in the air to add a zest and relish to-living. Each train, aa it pulled Into the station, left be hind its bevy of merry yonng people, and the village for a time assumed the airs and importance of a metrop olis. - Richmond, Lynchburg, Farm ville, Bhrkeville and Pamplin City, contributed to swell the crowd. By 9 oclock Cherwood was filled with the most beautiful and attract ive . gathering that has - ever a dis tinguished the social life of Appomat tox. The house was brilliantly illu minated and gracefully decorated, and it would require the pen and dis- criptive talent of a superhuman power to describe the exquisite toilets of jbe occasion. The yonng ladies in their beautiful -and varied oos tomes and the chivalry with their black evening suits and glossy white sfiift fronts made a pleasing and agreeable contrast as they sauntered in and out of the elegant apartments. Mrs. J. R. Atwood received in a cream brocade satin, point desprit lace and diamond ornaments. She was assisted by Mrs. Martin Harvey, Mrs. T. A. Woodson, Mrs. A. B. Da vis and Mrs. J. L. Chernault. The following is a list of the ladies present, and their toilets Miss Lizzie Weiiand in cream crepe de chine, velvet and ornaments. Miss Katie Franklin, of Pamplin City, red China silk and-cream lace. Miss Rosalie Wheeler, of Lynch burg, pink China silk and lace. Miss Sallie Burke, of this city, cream China silk with lace and rib bon trimmings. . Miss Lizzie Irby, of this city, White henrietta, ribbon and illusion trim mings. Mrs. J. W. Flood, of this county, black Bilk, chiffon, flowers and dia monds. Mrs. T. A. Woodson, of Lynch- bnrg, cream China silk, point desprit lace and diamonds. Mrs. A. B. Davis, of Farmville, black grenadine and satin. Mrs. J . L. Chernault, of Farmville, black satin, lace and diamonds. Miss Anna Jones, of this county, yellow China silk, pearl passafaen terie, cream lace and flowers. Miss Pearl Cunningham, of Farm ville, white embroidered mail, lace and diamonds. Miss Annie Abbitt, of this connty, cream China silk and lace Miss Nina Jones, of this county, yellow China silk and black chantilly lace. Miss Mattie Lee Cnnningbam, of Farmville, crepe cloth and lace. Miss Chassie Abbitt, of Farmville, black silk, lace and flowers. Miss Sarah B. Taylor, of Richmond, tan China silk, moss-green trim mings and pearls. Mrs. C. W. Hunter, heliotrope hen rietta, velvet and cream lace. Mrs. C. W. Hancock, black silk. Mrs. W. S. Royal, brown henrietta. Among the gentlemen present were Maj. J. W. Flood, Col. R. B. Poore, Dr. J. H. Abbitt, Dr. J. B. Abbitt, Rev. W. S. Royal, Rev. E. M. Craig, Prof. John Fisher, and Messrs. R Burke, C. W. Hancock, J. L. Cher nonit, Ben Holman, TT. A. Woodson, W. J. Trent, Wm. Fleshman, W. E Doss, John Stokes, Jos. Coleman W. H. Burke, G. C. Coleman, E. W Taylor, Wm. A. Moses, R. C. Harvey, and J. Mahone Miles. At eleven oclock refreshments were served and the table fairly groaned beneath, its weight of deli cacies. In the centre of the same was an immense pyramid, composed, of every frnit imaginable, and ar ranged so artistically that one might well have deemed it a picture. The feast included the fairest products of Summer and the daintiest morsels of Winter. Mr. E. Wiley Taylor, with his comic songs ana splendid imperson ations contributed much to- the en joyment of the gnests.
